awd_titl_txt: Assembly and Function of the Cyanobacterial Photosystem II Complex
awd_abstract_narration:
The photosystem II (PSII) complex found in plants, algae, and cyanobacteria is a chlorophyll-protein complex located in specialized internal cell membranes called thylakoids.  PSII catalyzes the crucial water-splitting reaction that uses solar energy to produce the activated hydrogen required for food and energy production throughout the Earth's biosphere.  At the same time, the PSII is responsible for the production of essentially all the gaseous oxygen on Earth.  Despite its global importance, PSII can also be considered the "Achilles Heel" of photosynthetic organisms.  This is because it is prone to damage from the very light that it uses as an energy source.  Consequently, PSII is under a constant state of repair owing to this incessant light damage. The project will elucidate the poorly understood repair mechanism with a focus on the assembly of the catalytic metals necessary for oxygen evolution. In addition to the fundamental research, the project will provide extensive training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in in the areas of biochemistry, biophysics, and molecular genetics.  Moreover, the is a large outreach component of the project that is designed to provide research opportunities for pre-service and in-service high school teachers. 

The project will investigate the multistep assembly of the metal cluster (Mn4CaO5) catalytic center of the PSII water-splitting complex.  Recent work has revealed the migration of damaged PSII to specialized "repair zones" located in the peripheral regions of the cell.  The project tests the hypotheses that (1) loss of the the Mn4CaO5 triggers the migration to repair zones and (2) the assembly of the Mn4CaO5 cluster occurs efficiently only after migration of the damaged PSII complex to these repair zones. Because light also drives Mn4CaO5 assembly, the process can be precisely controlled using flashes of light, which will allow new insights into the broad problem of metal cluster assembly in proteins. The work will use a genetically transformable cyanobacterium and an array of techniques that probe the assembly process with molecular resolution. State-of-the-art biophysical and molecular genetic techniques are being developed and utilized by the PI and collaborators.  These include synthetic DNA, high-speed polarography, EPR, and FTIR techniques.

por.por_cntn:
This project made critical advancements that were focused on illuminating the intricate processes of oxygenic photosynthesis. The spotlight of this investigation was Photosystem II (PSII), a vital component in the water-splitting reaction leading to oxygen production. By shedding light on the mysteries of PSII's water oxidation process and delving into the multi-step assembly of the Mn4CaO5 metal cluster, the project has significantly contributed to our understanding of biological energy conversion.  The project advanced fundamental knowledge in the areas of biophysics and biochemistry, particularly in the areas of metalloenzyme assembly and catalysis. This knowledge is paramount not only for comprehending life on Earth but also for innovating renewable energy solutions and food production in the face of global climate challenges.

Significance: Oxygenic photosynthesis depends upon the photosystem II (PSII), which catalyzes the complete oxidation of H2O molecules to O2. The electrons extracted from H2O-oxidation are the reductant for autotrophic metabolism and the liberated protons contribute to the transmembrane proton motive force powering ATP production.  The by-product, O2, has transformed our Earth?s atmosphere and makes heterotrophic life in the biosphere possible. An understanding of this process takes on added importance for efforts minimizing anthropogenic CO2 in the face of global warming. The development of carbon-neutral energy and chemical feedstock will likely include: 1.) natural or engineered photosynthetic organisms that produce valuable products; 2.) engineered devices that mimic the principals of natural photosynthesis by coupling light capture to charge separation and synthetic chemistry.

PSII and the Challenges of Repair: Despite significant progress, many facets of PSII, especially its repair mechanisms, have remained enigmatic. PSII is constantly under threat from photodamage, necessitating intricate repair mechanisms to replace the D1 protein at its core. Given that PSII is the beating heart of plant bioenergetics, its incessant repair is analogous 'open-heart surgery every thirty minutes,' highlighting the importance of understanding PSII assembly and repair. A central aspect of both these processes is the construction of the Mn4CaO5 complex, the catalytic center for water oxidation, through a light-driven process known as photoactivation. Understanding photoactivation is pivotal, not just for biological significance, but also for engineering 'self-repairing' water-oxidation catalysts and providing a unique model for metalloprotein assembly.

Molecular Insight to metalloprotein assembly: The project aimed to elucidate the mechanisms behind the photoactivation process, focusing on understanding why its efficiency depends on reaching a ?photoactivation competent state?. Our investigations revealed this state to be of molecular origin, linked to a conformational alteration of the metal binding site. A collaborative model was developed, incorporating structural information from various global research groups, shedding light on the role of calcium in the assembly process and suggesting a complex interaction involving protein structural changes and metal ion translocation.

Unraveling the Catalytic Mechanism: Building on previous work, the project explored the catalytic mechanism of water oxidation in PSII, discovering that mutations affecting hydrogen bonding among water ligands surrounding the metal cluster can profoundly affect catalysis. This led to strategic global collaborations and the development of innovative biochemical purification procedures, allowing for a detailed exploration of water oxidation?s transition state. A key finding was the identification of a rate-determining step requiring substantial entropic reorganization, a revelation with far-reaching implications for our understanding of catalysis and the development of biomimetic solar energy devices.

Empowering Educators through RET: A significant achievement of the project was the development and implementation of an innovative and highly effective Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) program. By immersing high school science teachers in a real research environment, coupled with professional development activities, the program enhanced science education in regional Oklahoma schools. This initiative provided teachers with a profound insight into scientific knowledge generation, enabling them to bring authentic research experiences into their classrooms and create standards-based inquiry curriculums.

Conclusion: The NSF-funded investigation has dramatically advanced our understanding of PSII's role in oxygenic photosynthesis, unveiling the complexities of the photoactivation process and the catalytic mechanism of water oxidation. These discoveries are invaluable for biological science, have potential applications in renewable energy technologies, and have significantly enhanced science education in Oklahoma. As the world grapples with the challenges of global warming, the knowledge generated from this project stands as a testament to the power of scientific inquiry and collaboration, lighting the way towards a sustainable future.
